No country can do this alone, however. COP27 reminds us that we all have a responsibility to take on the climate crisis, especially wealthy nations like the U.S.
And we passed the CHIPS and Science Act, which invests in climate-related R&D and semiconductor manufacturing, a critical component of many green technologies.
We passed the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, which is building a greener transportation system, a cleaner electric grid, and climate resilience.
We passed the Inflation Reduction Act, which is projected to cut our emissions significantly and greatly spur the deployment of clean energy in the U.S.
This year, we‚Äôve shown that climate action is possible‚Äîeven in a challenging political environment.
We have the technology, the know-how, and the talent to prevent the worst climate outcomes and mitigate the effects of the climate crisis. We only need the political will to follow through.
Every degree of global warming above pre-industrial levels puts us on a path toward further destruction and developing nations and marginalized communities face the greatest risk.

As UN Secretary General @antonioguterres said, we‚Äôre facing a ‚Äúcode red for humanity.‚Äù Already we have seen the devastating consequences of the climate crisis at home and abroad: extreme drought, wildfire, hunger, flooding, and more.

During #COP27 is a good time to reflect on the progress we‚Äôve made toward addressing the climate crisis & the work that remains to curb carbon emissions & build climate resilience. Legislation like the Inflation Reduction Act is a good start, but it isn‚Äôt all we can and must do.
